p: As scientifically reviewed elsewhere, thyme, oregano and certain cinnamon EOs, as well as their major constituents, carvacrol, cinnamaldehyde and thymol, are known to possess outstanding inhibitory potential against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria [ 3, 10, 13]. Therefore the MICs of thyme and oregano EOs can be set as the benchmark for other EOs. On this basis, it can be asserted that Azadirachta indica, Backhousia citriodora, Litsea cubeba and Nardostachys jatamansi exhibit comparably high antibacterial activity. These EOs were especially active against S. aureus, fully inhibiting its growth at 50 μg/ml (the lowest concentration tested). Furthermore, the EOs from these plants appear to be scientifically less well investigated in terms of antimicrobial activity, as only a small number of preliminary findings exist [ 19, 20, 21, 22].
